image.altText: A woman with pink hair, wearing a black dress, looks stoicly towards the camera with dark green foilage behind her.

items.synopsis: An email with a challenge sent us on a two-year journey to uncover what it's really like behind the closed doors of a rape trial.

title.children: Meagan set a challenge: a positive story about a rape trial. Two years on, here's the verdict

image.altText: Dozens of people of all ages line up outside a "For Lease" sign at a Sydney apartment building.

items.synopsis: There has been a lot of work going on behind the scenes in the lead up to National Cabinet's housing crisis meeting this week – and it could potentially mark an important shift in the way governments think about housing, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The housing crisis has formed in the middle of a nexus. The crunch needs to be answered

image.altText: Victoria Cafasso's killer has never been found.

items.synopsis: Italian tourist Victoria Cafasso had been in Tasmania barely a week in 1995 when she was stabbed 17 times on an idyllic beach in broad daylight. Twenty-seven years on, police release new images and reveal they have conducted recent searches.

title.children: Police conducting new searches over grisly unsolved beach murder of Italian tourist Victoria Cafasso

image.altText: A shorefront with burnt out cars and buildings.

items.synopsis: Cadaver dogs from California and Washington state are expected to arrive today to help with recovering human remains from the ruins, as firefighters work to extinguish hot spots and smaller fires.

title.children: Search for bodies begins after Maui wildfire, amid questions about whether residents received warning

image.altText: A burning building next to palm trees blowing in strong wind

items.synopsis: As a fire scientist, I know the unfolding horror — which has killed 53 people so far — is just the beginning. It's a portent of what Australia and other countries will experience in a warmer world, writes David Bowman.

title.children: 'Our fiery future': The unfolding horror in Hawaii holds a message for Australia

image.altText: Montage of six different female mining leaders and workers.

items.synopsis: A growing chorus of women from all levels of the mining sector are speaking out against gendered discrimination, bullying, a lack of opportunity and, at the extreme end, sexual harassment and assault.

title.children: 'This is not acceptable': Women in mining speak out against decades of sexual harassment and discrimination

image.altText: Zecira Misovic falls on the ground

items.synopsis: Earthquakes, goalscoring centre backs and another miraculous, albeit slightly sketchy, save by Swedish goalkeeper Zećira Mušović — here are the five quick hits from Friday's FIFA Women's World Cup quarterfinals.

title.children: Five quick hits — Sweden's super-keeper does it again and an earthquake rocks the FIFA Women's World Cup

image.altText: The Bushwalkers artwork showing a group of people outside.

items.synopsis: Southern Highlands baker Tracy Nickl was clearing out artwork from his grandfather's home when he nearly gave one worth more than a million dollars to an op shop until his friend, artist Ben Quilty, saw it.

title.children: Million-dollar painting that nearly ended up in op shop now bound for National Gallery

image.altText: A woman walking in a hallway with a trolley

items.synopsis: Stays in maternity hotels are becoming increasingly popular among Chinese women in Australia, with some new mothers paying up to $50,000 for 26 days.

title.children: Maternity hotels, meal services, nannies for newborns — the Chinese postnatal traditions catching on in Australia

image.altText: Two images stitched together - one shows a Tesco bag of onions, grown in NZ, and the other shows a field in NZ

items.synopsis: Food prices in New Zealand are growing at the fastest rate in more than 30 years, but there are hopes a new grocery regulator will change things.

title.children: NZ onions are cheaper in the UK. How the country is trying to fix its grocery problem

image.altText: A hand signs a signature with a pen at the end of a form or contract.

items.synopsis: Until now, millions of Australians have been saving in ways that you would expect – cutting back on discretionary items. But there's evidence that thriftiness has evolved to include what many might see as essential items, writes David Taylor.

title.children: From 'thrifty' to 'risky': The financial decisions more Australians are making to pay the mortgage

image.altText: Michelle Bullock and Philip Lowe

items.synopsis: RBA governor Philip Lowe says inflation is falling and the worst is over for interest rate increases, but rising property prices are complicating things.

title.children: RBA governor Philip Lowe says 'the worst is over' for interest rate rises, as his term nears its end

image.altText: James Redmond Burrows outside a court.

items.synopsis: Tasmanian tax agent James Redmond Burrows was entrusted with very large sums of money by his clients but "deliberately and systematically betrayed that trust over a lengthy period", a court has heard.

title.children: Tax accountant who stole nearly $1.5m from clients and tax office to fund gambling addiction jailed

image.altText: A man in a black shirt and cap crouches down next to a racing greyhound with a silk coat at a race track.

items.synopsis: Aerial footage taken at a Gary Johnson's greyhound facility is released by Animal Liberation Tasmania — with the trainer saying the presence of the drone had his animals "cowering like they've been interfered with".

title.children: 'There was nothing wrong': Greyhound trainer fires back at activist group over kennel drone footage

image.altText: A man sits on a rock

items.synopsis: A coroner has stopped parents of Luke Gilbert from giving their family impact statement after they refused to edit sections deemed "factually incorrect and offensive" by police.

title.children: Police shooting victim's swastika tattoos analysed as parents barred from making 'offensive' impact statement

image.altText: Laneway in bird's eye view show people waking towards barge

items.synopsis: Dozens of asylum seekers are evacuated from the Bibby Stockholm — a temporary accommodation barge off England's south coast — after health authorities found traces of Legionella bacteria in vessel's water system.

title.children: Asylum-seeker barge evacuated after traces of deadly bacteria found in water

image.altText: A man with grey hair and glasses next to a separate photo of a young Chinese-Australian woman smiling.

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese says a letter from Ms Cheng, who has been detained in China for three years, is "moving", but the relationship with China shouldn't become "transactional".

title.children: Release of Australian journalist not a condition for Beijing visit, prime minister says

image.altText: Pauline Hanson, dressed in a red jacket, wears a serious expression as she walks out of the Senate.

items.synopsis: A misleading viral video shared by One Nation leader Pauline Hanson and anti-Voice campaigners has sparked a wave of racial abuse towards an Aboriginal family and has left another couple feeling "crucified".

title.children: Families distressed after 'highly misleading' video used by anti-Voice campaigners goes viral

image.altText: Matty Healy performing on stage.

items.synopsis: The organiser of a Malaysian music festival is seeking 12.3 million ringgit ($4.11 million) in losses from British band The 1975, after its lead singer's on-stage protest of the country's anti-gay laws prompted authorities to shut the event down.

title.children: Organisers of cancelled Malaysian festival seek $4.1 million from UK band The 1975 over same-sex kiss

image.altText: Sam Kerr stands on the sidelines with her arms folded during warm-ups for the Matildas' Women's World Cup clash with Denmark.

items.synopsis: Tony Gustavsson backs his captain and superstar striker to start on the field in the Matildas' Women's World Cup quarterfinal against France, but only if she is fit enough to play 90-plus minutes.

title.children: 'If Sam is fit to play 90 minutes, she is starting': Matildas coach unequivocal on Kerr's place for quarterfinal

image.altText: A gorup of four female soccer players in green and gold jerseys hug each other in celebration.

items.synopsis: If you're a novice who wants keep up with the chat about the Matildas, it helps to know the rules of the game. Get up to speed in a few minutes.

title.children: Jumping on the Matildas bandwagon? Here are some key rules to know

image.altText: Four men in handcuffs stand with sheriff's officers outside a yellow brick building

items.synopsis: The underworld connections of one of the four men responsible for a fatal bashing in an Adelaide school car park three years ago can be revealed for the first time, after a South Australian judge allowed a suppression to be lifted.

title.children: School car park killer revealed as son of bikie executed on Gold Coast

image.altText: Tayla Cox wears pink and holds her baby girl Murphy

items.synopsis: The bodies of Tayla Cox and 11-week-old daughter Murphy were found by police on Thursday morning.

title.children: Queensland mother who was found dead at home with baby girl was a 'beacon of hope, joy and love'

image.altText: a man sitting on a bench

items.synopsis: A new principal and teacher are working to attract students back to a small school in regional Western Australia after a mass exodus, saying the school is the heart of the town.

title.children: This is Sean, principal of a school with no students. But he plans to change that, one child at a time

image.altText: A primary school with a noticeboard out front that reads "Campbell Primary School".

items.synopsis: An Integrity Commission hears an Education Directorate official was told: "That's not what the minister's office wants" when he revealed the winner of the Campbell Primary School refurbishment tender.

title.children: Education official allegedly told 'that's not what the minister's office wants' after revealing winner of school refurbishment tender

image.altText: a man stands next to a school bus

items.synopsis: The principal of an Alice Springs school whose students allegedly broke in and stole a bus says it is "another punch in the guts" as a local member says the children "rocked back up to school" the next day.

title.children: Tyre spikes used after eight students under 12 allegedly steal bus from Alice Springs school

image.altText: Collingwood players surround a smiling teammate who has kicked a goal.

items.synopsis: Collingwood overcomes more injury problems and a determined Geelong side to produce a brilliant comeback for a win at the MCG.

title.children: No Daicos, no Moore, no problem as Pies down the Cats at MCG

image.altText: Reece Walsh jumps on Billy Walters as Brisbane Broncos teammate Ezra Mam celebrates nearby.

items.synopsis: As they prepare to return home to Lang Park, the Broncos hammer Parramatta 54-10 to extend their winning streak to six matches heading into a bye week.

title.children: Broncos farewell Gabba with nine-try thumping of Eels, who lose Moses to suspected broken cheekbone

image.altText: An Aboriginal man wearing a cap stands in front of a sculpture of a tree covered in birds

items.synopsis: Keith Wikmunea is among the artists awarded prizes at Australia's most prestigious Indigenous art awards for his sculptural piece.

title.children: Queenland 'master of carving' takes out Australia's top Indigenous art prize

image.altText: Emma Walters appears serious as she walks out of the Melbourne Magistrates' Court.

items.synopsis: Emma Walters had been charged with plotting to kill her former partner John Setka, but police have now dropped those and other serious charges. She still faces other charges.

title.children: Police drop serious charges against Emma Walters, wife of union boss John Setka

image.altText: A man with a metal bucket.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for Alex Agelopolous, 23, tell a Melbourne court he will plead guilty to storming AAMI Park with a large group of Melbourne Victory fans last December, an incident described by the magistrate as “a great day of shame” for Australian football.

title.children: 'A great day of shame': Melbourne Victory fans plead guilty over violent pitch invasion

image.altText: Men work inside an underground coal mine.

items.synopsis: South32 says it will have to stand down some staff at Appin mine during the strike, which has been launched amid a dispute over leave arrangements and a productivity bonus.

title.children: Mine partially shut down as workers demand 'fair share of the pie'

image.altText: An Asian woman standing behind a coffee machine.

items.synopsis: Cafes and restaurants saw a boom of big-spending customers after the pandemic. Now, as cost-of-living pressures bite households and the cost of doing business grows, some in the hospitality industry are struggling to stay afloat.

title.children: A perfect storm is brewing at Lillian's cafe: Rising costs and fewer customers coming through the door

image.altText: A side profile of a blonde woman with glasses and a black turtleneck

items.synopsis: WA Liberals Leader Libby Mettam says she will vote no in the Voice referendum, after previously saying she would back the Yes campaign.

title.children: WA Liberal Leader changes stance on Voice vote, blaming cultural heritage laws saga

image.altText: Amar Singh standing in front of a truck that is painted in Indigenous art

items.synopsis: Australian of the Year Local Hero award winner Amar Singh will be voting Yes — he says that decision is based on "fairness".

title.children: Amar Singh thought the referendum could be better communicated to multicultural communities, so he's touring the country
